title: Middle Eastern & North African Diasporic Narratives: The Memoir as History
xlist: Same As: ER&M 340, section 01
yc_attrs: This course can be applied towards the Humanities and Arts Yale College distributional requirement.
description: Our course examines memoirs alongside major historical and political movements in the Middle East and North Africa in the late 20th and 21st centuries. Telling their stories alongside Pan-Arabism, the Iranian Revolution, the Syrian Wars, Gaddafi’s Regime, and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, these writers examine history, politics, and war in relation to their familial upheaval, geographic displacement, diasporic identities, coming of age, and gender and sexuality. We discuss the way these writers navigate different aesthetic forms to bear witness to their overlapping personal and political stories, their attention to archival, historical, and intimate details, the politics of narrating the stories of others, and the intertwined gendered, ethnic, and religious dynamics of their narratives. In addition to examining literary and graphic memoirs, we examine other cultural productions (documentary film, installations, and photography) that bear witness to the personal, political, and historical implications of displacement.
instructordetail_html:
